Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Patient-Specific Instrumentation in Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: Forty patients were randomised into two groups

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included patients scheduled for primary TKA. The study was conducted at a single orthopedic center.

Intervention.evidence: randomised into two groups: PSI and conventional instrumentation

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to evaluate whether patient-specific instrumentation (PSI) in total knee arthroplasty (TKA) improves patient-reported outcomes and gait compared to conventional instrumentation.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was walking speed, measured using a 3-D gait analysis system, with a clinically important difference set at 0.1 m/second.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Forty patients were randomised into two groups

Number_Analysed.evidence: All 40 patients completed the study and were analyzed using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Both groups showed improvements in functional scores, quality of life, and gait parameters. However, no significant differences were found between the PSI and conventional groups in KSS, KOOS, SF-12, or gait parameters.
